body.value: ZNH introduces Mule on the Mount in response to questions by Halpert: In the juke houses and doing any kind of work at all, chopping wood and in the lumber camps and everywhere you find this song. No where you can't find parts of this song, Mule on the Mount.
HH: Is it a consistent song as you hear it all over?
ZNH: The tune is consistent but the verses, you know how things, in every locality you can find some new verses, everywhere.
HH: Does it have Mule on the Mount wherever you hear it?
ZNH: Well, there's some place that I haven't heard that same verse Mule on the Mount but there's no place that I don't hear some of the same verses.
HH: Where did you learn this particular way?
ZNH sings Mule on the Mount
HH asks how many verses are typically sung.
ZNH responds: Sometimes they sing 30 and 40 verses . . . it's one of these things that grown by incremental repetition until perhaps it's the longest song in America.

HH introduces Beatrice Lange who begins telling folk stories that her brother-in-law told her, and who, this old negro of his told him about it. The story is a hurricane story that happens in 1898. Lange reads it from notes.
ZNH introduces Let the Deal Go Down Boy; gambling song, collected at Boston Florida; The men are playing a game called Georgia skin; ZNH explains the rules.
ZNH sings Let the Deal Go Down

ZNH introduces Uncle Bud: Uncle Bud is not a work song; it's a sort of social song for amusement and it's so widely distributed, it's growing all the time by incremental repetition. Halpert asks, is it sung before the respectable ladies? Never!, ZNH says, it's one of those jook songs and the woman that they sing Uncle Bud infront of is a jook woman.
ZNH sings Uncle Bud.
ZNH: I know I know some more verses but right off I don't recall.
HH: I think that's a very valuable contribution to scientific recording.

ZNH introduces Oh the Buford Boat Done Come: a song from the Geechee country in South Carolina but I heard it down in Florida from a Geechee that moved down in Florida. I forget her name right now . . . it's a little dance song with a Charleston rhythmn.
HH: How do they play it? Can you tell us very quickly?
ZNH: Uh, it's just a dance song and then they dance a Charleston rhythm on it . . . group dancing . . . any working group and they'll clap their hands on it and sing.
ZNH introduces: I'm a sing a Blues, Cuz Ever Been Down and I got it at Palm Beach from a fellow named from Johnny Bardon.
HH: Where did you get it
ZNH: I got it in 1933.
HH: Can you tell me, do you know how old a Blues it is? And how you happened to learn it?

ZNH: Well, it's one of those things just go around all the jooks and what not like that and it goes by incremental repetition, a verse here and a verse there. I don't suppose anyone knows how old it is and when it started.
ZNH sings Cuz Ever Been Down
ZNH introduces Halimufack: I was in a big crowd and I learned it in the evening from the crowd. I don't remember who did teach it to me but I learned it from the crowd.
ZNH sings Halimufack
HH: You said you learned it in a crowd. How do you learn most of your songs?

ZNH: I learn them. I just get in the crowd with the people if they singing and I listen as best I can and I start to joining in with a phrase or two and then finally I get so I can sing a verse and then I keep on until I learn all the songs, all the verses, and then I sing them back to the people until they tell me I can sing it just like them and then I take part and I try it out on different people who already know the song until they are quite satisfied I know it and then I carry it in my memory.
HH: Well how about those you have in your books or that you publish in the journals?
ZNH: Well, that's the same way I got them. I learn the song myself and then I can take it with me wherever I go.

ZNH introduces Tampa: this is a song called Tampa. I've known it ever since I could remember so I don't know who taught it to me but I heard it sung in my native village when I was a child, not in front of the old folks, of course.
ZNH sings Tampa
HH asks a question.

ZNH: I've known it all my life. No, it was not confined to children. Everybody sung and danced on it. And you hear a Negro orchestra, a local orchestra, they often played it now, played the tune. They don't sing the words but the tune is one of their favorite dance tunes.

ZNH introduces Po Boy, Po Gal: This one. Some of them call it Po Boy and some of them call it Po Gal but it's a pretty well-distributed blues tune all over the South. The words are not rhymed. It's a typical Negro pattern. The same line repeated three times with a sort of flip line on the end and the change is in the tune rather than the words for the most part.
HH: Where did you pick up the way you sing it?
ZNH: I'm - not all my life but I kept learning verses as I've gone around.
ZNH sings Po Boy

ZNH introduces Mama don't want no peas no rice is a song from Nasssau in the Bahama islands. They are great song makers and their tunes are more African than the ones made my the negroes in America. They make songs so rapidly they say anything you do we put you in sing. And in a few hours they have a song about it. Mama don't want no peas no rice is about a woman who wanted to stay drunk all the time and her husband is really complaining about it. He's explaining to the neighbors what's the matter with his wife and why they don't get along better.
ZNH sings Mama don't no peas and rice.
HH and Evelyn Werner, 32, born and raised in Jacksonville, telling a story about plantation life.
HH: Dr. Corse would you please explain why we asked to have this record made?

CC: This record was made for the purpose of recording the anunciation of an edcuated Southern white voice. And the story was one which was recorded by the Federal Writers as part of their work for the American guide series volume that's Florida.
[educated white woman]
HH: Dr. Corse will please introduce the speaker?
CC: This is Mrs. Rollis Southworth, State Director of the Professional Service Projects of the WPA in Florida who will give us her opinion of the recording program of the folk songs in Florida.

RS: Well, Dr. Corse it would reallly seem that we have finally grown up as a nation that we can spend the day recording such folklore as we have heard today. And this is only the beginning and in only one city. Think of the endless material alone throughout Florida. Now although we are in the deep South, our state, with Mr. Call, has a very cosmopolitan group. As a matter of fact, the flags of five nations have flown over Florida. Isn't that fact? And what wealth of material that will indicate. Personally, my greatest interest is in the Negro Folklore and how justly proud we all are of Zora Hurston whose fine literary ability and wealth of experience has made our recordings possible today.
ZNH: Thank you Ms. Southworth.
HWS: My name is H. W. Stuckey. I'm 43 years old. I'm a WPA instructor for the blind.
HH: you are also a preacher, aren't you, sir? What congregation?
HWS: A missionary Baptist
HH: Now, uh, this isn't part of your usual, as a missionary baptist, does your church approve of singing?
HWS: No sir, no sir, they do not.
HH: Youre going to help us out with these?
HWS: Yes sir, In order to preserve these songs of mine from my childhood days on a farm in South Carolina.
HWS sings
HH: That, that, what would you call that?

HWS: It's a farm song, made up between the boys plowing on two or more plantations; one would holler Hi-Lo and the other would answer with a second Hi-Lo. That would be a signal for knocking off time for noon, for dinner.
HH: What would be the effect of actually being out on the farm?
HWS sings.
HWS: The fish vendor?
ZNH guides HH in his question from the background: the one without the words
HWS: It was usually used in the afternoon mostly when the boys were knocking off work and going in to clean up or going out to call on their girls at night.
HWS sings
HH: Where would the two of them be?

HWS: Well, it'd be in the afternoon and they usally had one big plantation a well where the boys from the different fields would water their stock. And they would be unhooking from the plower, the planters, and distributers, and going to water their mules and put them in the lot for the night. When they start these hollers.
HH: Would they be near each other?
HWS: possibly sometimes a quarter mile or a half a mile away
HH: Would you do it again? Was it the same effect between a quarter mile . . . do a quarter mile.
HW Stuckey sings
HWS: Shall I make an explanation of this? Yes sir.

HWS: introduces the song: during my early childhood days in Lee County, SC, my brother-in-law used to carry me about with him at night to these old fashioned dances and he called sets. They would also send for him for 10 or 15 miles around to come and call sets. And one of the songs that I remember well is like this.
HWS sings
HH: Are there more verses to that?
HWS: No that's all I remember.
HWS sings.
HH: Those last directions, is that what he would call out? What kind of dancing were they doing?
HWS: Old fashioned slow dancing is all I knew. Sorry.

HW Stuckey introduces his song: There was an old gentleman when I was a little boy in Sumter, South Carolina, who used to go around the streets selling fish. And this was the song that he would sing in the morning as he came down Manning Avenue where I lived and other streets throughout the city and could be heard for quite a distance, several blocks, singing.
HW Stuckey sings.
HH: asks a question.
HW Stuckey: Yes, sir, I wrote, 9 or 10 years old.
HW Stuckey sings.

HWS: During my early boyhood days I had to nurse my sister's children. I wasn't . . . being my sight being affected I would not work on the farm and they made me nurse the children. These are some of the songs I liked to sing with the babies in my arms in the, under the tree shade or sometimes on the porch.
HWS sings.
Irene Jackson, 40, South Jacksonville, FL, singing a song they called play church
ZNH: Go ahead
IJ sings
HH: You used to play games to that?
iJ: Well, we would be having service and it was for our preacher to preach though. He couldn't preach out the bible so we'd just take a word and add on and go to preaching. We'd be out in the yard.
IJ sings
IJ explains: The closing part of children's sermon that we used to have.
IJ sings.
Alabama Singleton, 33, Savannah, GA introduces a southern ring play.
AS sings.
AS introduces a song.
AS sings.
AS introduces a song.
AS sings.
AS sings.
HH adjusts the microphone
Maggie Fulton, 43, introduces a game, learned in Leesville, SC.
MF sings a song.
MF explains a game.
MF sings a song.
MF demonstrates a game.
Man, 30 yrs old, born in Georgia, reared in Florida, a water boy on the marlboro camp, introduces a song.
Man sings a song.
Man sings a song.

Man explains they would sing the song to themselves aroused again in warm weather, to get more interesting in their work, driving mules. They would sing the song as the mule was going up and down the grade, loading. The name of the song is John Henry. The men during the day would sing this while they drove spikes.   . . . the same tune all the time but different wording. They would make up the words.
